clinical_study.brief_title: Vaginal Progesterone Supplementation in the Management of Preterm Labor
clinical_study.official_title: Vaginal Progesterone Supplementation in the Management of Preterm Labor: A Randomized, Double Blind, Controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock: This study evaluates the addition of vaginal progesterone in the management of preterm labor. Half of participants will receive vaginal progesterone, tocolysis and corticosteroid, while the other half will receive only tocolysis and corticosteroid.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: Time from preterm labor pain to delivery
primary_outcome.description: time since preterm labor to delivery

secondary_outcome.measure: number of pregnant women deliver before 34 weeks
number of pregnant women deliver before 37 weeks
Number of newborn with respiratory distress syndrome
secondary_outcome.description: Number of newborn with respiratory distress syndrome

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of newborn with intraventricular hemorrhage
secondary_outcome.description: Number of newborn with intraventricular hemorrhage

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of newborn with necrotizing enterocolitis
secondary_outcome.description: Number of newborn with necrotizing enterocolitis

arm_group.description: Vaginal utrogestan 400 mg, vaginal suppository, once at bed time until gestational age 37 weeks and tocolysis plus corticosteroid for 48 hours
only tocolysis plus corticosteroid for 48 hours

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- singleton pregnant women with preterm labor, gestational age 24-34 weeks
Exclusion Criteria:
- have indicated preterm birth
- allergy to progesterone
- fetal anomalies
- cervical dilate > 5 cm.
- have medical disease
- have obstetric complication
